item.title: hopefully
item.description:
hopefully…

hopefully more smiles and beach days

hopefully less drought, fire and hot winds

hopefully health and freedom

hopefully more beaches

hopefully

item.title: monochromes part 2
On becoming a citizen of the United States of America.
item.description:
On the 18th of August 2017 I became a citizen of the United States. I didn’t exactly rush into this, I had already lived in the US for about 20 years. But there becomes a time when you start to care about what is happening around you. You understand things at a deeper level and have a concern for the shared future.

I didn’t need to become a citizen, as a permanent resident you can do pretty much everything a citizen can. In my case it was more about making a commitment and recognising the reality I was living. Living there all those years I never encountered any feelings that made me feel like outsider or pushed me to citizenship. My American family were always welcoming and treated me very much as one of them. Americans as a rule are welcoming and often curious about outsiders and life beyond. It’s how the country started and continues today - and unfortunately, in some parts it doesn’t hurt to be an English speaking white guy.

The only times I ever felt really ‘apart’ were during interactions with the immigration process. An immigration office nurse speaking to me in Spanish - a blank stare from me - and prompting my wife to dryly point out that ‘he speaks English’. More sinister were the rent-a-cop security guards who tried prevent me from accessing a critical appointment at the immigration office - a fake uniform combined with a gun, and lots of petty power over peoples future. I feel for those less language fluent and less aware of how the system works.

So on that day my wife and I walked to the federal courthouse in Reno, and after months of filling in forms, and attending interviews and tests, I was sworn-in as a citizen. The judge in his speach pointed out that one of the roles of a citizen was to understand our new country and to make an effort to learn about the issues that face it. That often there are no easy answers and many things can take thought, curiosity and a search for knowledge to discover truth.

Finally I remember the woman in the red dress. It was cut low, fitted and completely “inappropriate” for such an important day. And like many things in Nevada easy to judge wrongly. The judge asked if any of the newly minted citizens had any observations. The woman in the red dress spoke. She had grown up in the middle-east and spoke of the repression and dogma that women endure. She did not want this for herself, and importantly for her daughter. She wanted them to live a country that was free for a woman to act and live as they choose - and so she wore the dress that day, because she could. With tears I remembered how blessed I have been to live in and be a citizen of two free countries.

As we walked home along familiar streets, everything felt slightly and importantly different, I now belonged in a fundamental way.

Photos - Kemah, Texas July 4th parade 2009.

item.title: The beach - part 2
item.description: Sunny fun at the beach…not today.

item.title: The spring flowers have arrived...
item.description: It’s spring down-under and the new seasons flowers have arrived. This seasons model does not care for what happened before, what their predecessors overcame or what happened then - it’s about now, their chance. They are pushing and growing their way into the garden, our thoughts and our lives, and they are making a point - the season will change no matter what we do. Seasons change, time passes and life goes on.

item.title: Pelicans - Part Two
item.description: Pelicans

item.title: Sunsets
item.description: For every sunrise there is a sunset…

item.title: Yellow-tailed Black Cockatoo
item.description:
Seeing a lot of these guys around here of late. They are big birds that fly slowly with large sweeping wings and their heads down, while making an almost primeval wail. While they seem gentle they also seem other-worldly, especially when a flock arrives. They are the inspiration for many bush legends and dreamtime stories, and I can see why.

Yellow-tailed black cockatoo - Wikipedia

item.title: Cloudy day...
item.description:
It was a cloudy day at the beach at Old Bar.

Old Bar is on the Mid-north coast of NSW and is on the south side of the Manning River delta. The Manning is reputed to be the only river with two openings to the sea in the southern hemisphere.

item.description: Recently scene in the back yard.

item.title: monochromes
item.description: feeling a bit well … colourless.

item.title: Winter in the Tablelands
item.description: Steam rises off a metal fence as the morning sun melts a thick overnight frost. Tenterfield, in the Northern Tablelands region of NSW Australia, near the Queensland border.

item.title: Backyard beauty.
item.description: June 1st marks the start of winter in Australia. For much of the country winter is a mild, high rainfall season - so many plants keep growing, bees keep busy and life goes on. These beauties in our backyard don’t seem to mind the cooler weather at all.

item.title: The day the ocean got angry
item.description:
The day warm, the sand soft golden with blue cheer overhead and a warm whisper breeze … but the ocean was angry, roiled and grumpy. Needing to explode, push stuff around. Unsatisfied and with nowhere to focus it’s energy except for pounding the beach. Just because it can and not care who got hurt.

Nobody went out that day, that much power without form or grace can be ugly, scary and brutal.

item.title: Approaching Equilibrim
item.description: The sculpture Approaching Equilibrim by Anthony Pryor is located at the Brisbane Cultural Centre

item.title: Pelicans of the Texas Gulf Coast
item.description: Pelicans living and playing at various locations near Galveston, Texas.

item.title: going it alone
item.description:
Going solo…breaking from the pack…beyond the sound advice, the community of comfort, influence and socials, missing the what’s expected and should’ve beens. That place where we choose what matters - to us.

Going solo. It’s easy to say, makes for good movie dialogue, but is scary when it’s your own life and the risks are real. It’s your mistakes, hurts, losses and waste. That quintessential way to F UP with nobody to blame but yourself.

So why travel away from the comfort and safety of the pack? Safety and comfort can be imagined or ephemeral. A decision not made or deferred, is a decision; a word unspoken, is a word; and silence is a sound. There is no such thing as safety in numbers, and the herd does not always know what to do.

For solo travellers the silence of doubt and even fear, can sometimes be the loudest noise we hear. Not every solo story is a happy one, and they don’t always have clean endings or less pain. But we still do them, because they are what we are…

item.title: ...and then it rained.
item.description:
Finally it rained.

We have seen fires before. We have seen droughts before. Felt the parched winds, choking smoke, the smouldering black ash in scarred silent bushland, farmlands of dust, the destruction and hurt. Drought’s end, fires extinguish, rains come and new life is created from the old - it’s part of the cycle. The bush heals, green grows from black wood and dust becomes soil again, and what was lost is re-grown.

Maybe she’ll be right. Maybe things have changed, something precious lost and damaged for good. We don’t know anymore - shadows of doubt are cast - and that is new.

item.title: Kookaburras
item.description: If there is a king of the Australian bush it may be the Kookaburra. The Magpie has her wonderful songs and always seems to be up to something playful, the Crow is somehow darker - maybe it knows too much, but the Kookaburra smiles and laughs and quietly looks over all.

item.title: Lorikeets!
item.description:
These are Rainbow Lorikeets, a kind of parrot, which are common in parts of Australia.

Lorikeets are hugely colourful and as happens sometimes, are also blessed with a loud grating call. A group of them can sound like a real ruckus. They can be greedy grumpy birds and won’t let other, even larger birds like crows and magpies, near their food.

I would like to pretend that these were taken after days of meticulous location research and trekking, but the neighbour feeds them and they hang out on her clothes line and fence.

item.title: Vision and seeing.
item.description:
Things are not always what they seem. What we “see” blends with what is actually there - and we don’t know which is which. In fact we may have no way of knowing what is actual - just stuff my mind, your mind, or someone else’s perceives.

In physics there is no colour - our brain and eyes create colours out of a narrow bands of visible light frequencies. There is no warm or cold - just kinetic energy. And there are no guaranteed outcomes and certainties - just higher chances that something may happen in a random quantum world. The world we know is a hallucination that our mind manufactures - to make sense of it all - whatever that is.[1]

Unlike what we learned in school - life, and reality in general has few, if any well defined, correct or wrong answers. It’s all a bit of a muddle. If our mind’s are different, then what we see, think and do will also be different.

[1] “Our Inner Universes” by Anil K Seth, Scientfic American September 2019

item.title: Selfies
item.description: Working through a series of photo exercises from a book. Told to take self-portraits. Don’t like doing that. Here they are.

item.title: Parents...
item.description:
Earlier this year I took some photos of objects that reminded me of my parents. It allowed me to capture some memories of them as their possessions start to disappear. And it gave me an opportunity think about them and reflect on their lives.

My Mum’s old school bag. As a kid I remember her keeping cosmetics in it, later in her life she used it to store medicines. She always found a role for it, and maybe needed it to have one.

My Mum lived alone for many years and liked to have little toys and dolls around the house, all with faces.

My Dad was an electrical engineer and a bit of a free thinker. He strongly believed that individuals given effective communication and collaboration tools would help cause meaningful change in society. He also helped design electrical substations for the local energy supply authority - a very conservative organisation. He is the one standing on the right.

item.title: Emigrate
item.description:
California became a part of the United States in 1850 but even before then people living in the eastern parts of the US desired to go there. In more recent times the annual nationwide TV broadcast of the The Rose Parade on New Years Day - usually a pleasant sunny day in the Los Angeles area - is roumoured to help re-kindle that desire to those shivering through brutal East Coast and mid-western winters.

To get to get to California from the east, before the Transcontintial Rail Line and interstate road system were built, you had two choices, a very long arduous sea journey around South America, or a long arduous and dangerous across-country trip by land. The technologies used - covered wagons and horses - would not be unfamiliar to medieval travellers. After completing most of the land journey across desert expanses and hostile territory there was one final hazard. The Sierra Nevada Mountains which form a natural large north-south barrier between California and the states to the east.

Emigrant Gap is a pass over the top of the Sierra Nevada range between Reno, Nevada and Sacramento, California in the west. West of Donner Pass, Emmigrant Gap offered a plateau between the ascent on the eastern side and the decent on the California side.

Deckchairs on Zephyr Cove Beach, looking out to the peaks of the Sierra Nevada across Lake Tahoe.

Looking west from Arizona, across the Colorado River and into Nevada.

Beyond Emigrant Gap there are still rocks bearing scars of wagons and the ropes used to lower the wagons where the way was too steep. If the deserts or frozen winters hadn’t stopped them, the mountains still could, and sometimes did.

“It was a splendid population - for all the slow, sleepy, sluggish-brained sloths stayed at home - you never find that sort of people among pioneers - you cannot build pioneers out of that sort of material.” - Mark Twain, Roughing It

item.title: Views of the Roma Street Parklands
item.description:
The Roma Street Parklands is a hillside area near the centre of the city of Brisbane, Queensland . “Thousands of Eyes” by Yayoi Kusama is an artwork in the open-space outside the Brisbane Supreme Court and District Court building located at the foot of the Parklands .

The Old Windmill - Wickham Terrace, Brisbane. The old mill sits at a high point in Brisbane and probably once had a great view down to the Brisbane River. It’s claimed to be the oldest surviving (I suspect European) structure in Queensland and was built in 1828 to provide way to both feed and punish convicts. The sign next to it says it was used primarily to mill locally grown wheat and maize. Quoting the sign, “Two sets of mills stones, one driven by the sails and the other by the treadmill, provided the means of grinding the grain.”

It ceased to be used as a mill in the 1840’s and was converted in 1861 to a be a signal station to communicate with ships making their way up the river. Information from the ships was the communicated to the public using flags hoisted on the masts above the tower. It also served as an observatory and a fire observation outlook. In 1934 it was used to broadcast the first experimental TV signals in Queensland.

You can’t see the river anymore from the windmill as other much taller buildings now block the way. This is a night view looking down to the Brisbane River from the near the Parklands.

item.title: The Beach
item.description:
It’s more than a word, it’s more than a place, more than sand, waves and sun. The beach is memories, laughter, feelings and passions. A place to share - sometimes alone, a fleeting joy that we will always remember, a search for peace that finds ourselves.

As with many such things there is a tinge of danger, we frolic on the edge of where the earth - our domain - stops, and the domain of the water starts. We can visit, but the deep beyond can take us - an keep us - if it chooses.

The Beach at Old Bar, NSW.

item.title: Galveston statues
item.description:
Galveston is a city and a island on the Texas gulf coast, south of Houston. A location that confronts nature and is often punished by it. On August 27th, 1900 the then large city was hit by a hurricane - a bad one. There was no sea wall, no warning and no escape - we will probably never know how many were lost, but this event became the worst natural disaster in US history. Galveston as a city never fully recovered and the city of Houston grew and flourished at its expense.

Galveston Storm Memorial

Stacked rock sculpture on Galveston beach

item.title: Remembering trains
item.description:
There is a train museum to the south of Sydney near the town of Thirlmere.

My Dad took me there when I was a little kid. It’s a bit out of the way so he must have meant to go there. We always used to have to clear trips like that with my Mum who didn’t like us to drive too far in the family car. I remember the trains very well, down to small details, in one case the engine type, its colour and even its number. I just remember that day long ago very well. My Dad took me to a lot of places and I remember some of them very well, and some not. I thought I remembered everything I needed to about the Thirlmere visit.

Then I found some photos I took that day and I remembered something I had forgotten in all my memories - my Dad. Photos can do that.

So here they are, grainy old pictures of trains…and my dad.

item.title: The road goes west...
item.description:
Something about the American west harks to the open-road and the possibilities that beckon from beyond the horizon. As the heart grows restless… change things, go west, move on.

Heading north on highway US 95 towards Hawthorne and Mount Grant, Nevada.

Granite Dells near Precott, Arizona.

Granite Dells.

Off highway I-10 in Arizona.

Looking west from highway I-93, south of Las Vegas and Lake Mead.

item.title: The light at Crowdy Head
item.description:
Crowdy Head is on the north side of the Manning River where it opens to the sea. Before the roads were useful much of the produce and timber from river towns like Taree and Wingham was transported by costal steamers. These boats needed to make the difficult entry to the Manning and the lighthouse was built to assist with navigation. More about the lighthouse here.

I have visited Crowdy Head and photographed the lighthouse many times, here are some of the results.
